Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2009 07:30PM sanaisa wrote: I love coming on here...unklez...you nailed that one..."mud mouth"! I have already gone through my first bottle of Biotene and am on to my second! Poor little taste buds and nose...nothing smells or tastes right, I agree!! I don't recognize my favorite perfume that I have worn for years...actually, it (and just about any fragrance) repulses me... so strange!!!? Aw Anita!  Hang in there...yes, the first week is difficult.  I had pain in the same places...I honestly felt that recovering from my port surgery was more painful than my 2x breast surgeries.  I know, that sounds crazy.  Everyone on here is correct though, the port is good and saves our arm veins.  I have to use my port for a full year as while my 6 TCH treatments are "expected" to be finished in December, I have to continue with the "H" part of for a total of 18 treatments every 3 weeks (because of my +HER2)...so I won't be officially finished with these poking IV's in my port until September 2010.  I am so looking forward to getting #3 on 10/8/09 over with...that will be my "1/2" way mark for the full blown TCH chemos... but I hear the taste buds remain "off" throughout the "H"...a whole year? :(  But, they say the hair supposedly starts to grow back after the TC...you guys keeping up?!  ;) Melinda...yes! Carbs, carbs, carbs... pototoes, pasta, bread and yogurt! I am normally a salt lover...add salt to most things.  But after chemo for about 10 days, salt anything burns my mouth and tastes awful!  I have super cut down on the sodium intake...that must be a good thing.  Plus, lots of water!!!!  Mrsb...happy birthday! I hope you had some birthday cake! Sounds good! I had my first chemo two days before my birthday...kind of a strange b-day, but, I'll never forget that one.  Neither will you!  I guess having today's AC be the last on in that series today is a GREAT way to celebrate! Yay! You're now done with that chapter and moving on to the final Taxol x 12 weeks!  I hope your arm will be better very soon...! Marie, I don't know of any tips for building up veins...but look what I found when I googled this for you...right in our own backyard! :)  http://www.breastcancer.org/treatment/chemotherapy/ask_expert/question_28.jsp Take care everyone...chat soon!
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2009 11:26PM sanaisa wrote: Oh so sorry Brunettesrule... so many lessons we learn in the process.  I hope your chemo IV was overall successful.  Not that it should make you feel any better, but when I am "on time", it takes close to 7 hours for all my IV's to be infused as each one takes 2 hours, plus about an hour for the dexamethasone steriod that they start me on, which put me in practical dire staits last round. Tomorrow is round number three... So sorry to hear your news...I think I will bring my laptop tomorrow...I hope you are doing okay today. All...here's a fascinating article that came out last Monday (Nobel Prize Winners): http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aCjsSYk8WoUY
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2009 06:30AM sanaisa wrote: unklezwifeonty, I am laughing so hard!!! "You don't want to feel like cactus masses are coming out when things eventually open up."  Oh my!!! Wowsers!  I am taking all your advice for 22 grapes, MOM, Senna-S...thank you, thank you, THANK YOU!  And, I can still laugh at the whole "movement".  Oh boy.  Yes, it seemed the nether-region began to sparse before the head on me.  Pretty crazy, this losing the hair process.  My hair's still growing, but it is much finer and more of a downy appearance (much like the photo of the nurse you see in the middle left when you first sign on to breastcancer.org.).  Free cleaning for cancer patients? That would be nice... Anita, keep us posted about your foot...and what's this about your wig?  How long do you wear it for?  You have it attached, then removed/cleaned, and then reattached?  Is that a lace wig?  How long does it last? Can you wash you hair in it, or, how does it work?  Very interesting... I agree Lisaa401...working full time has been very helpful for me.  I work in HR, so I am a caregiver of my employees (taking care of them all the time).  Sometimes I feel likeI am everyone's mother here, kind of funny.  I love my job and everyone has been so supportive. I have only missed work on chemo days because those treatments take about 7 hours, plus one bad day due to the steriods.  I keep hearing that we should anticipate the possibility of at least one hospitalization during this process (fever/infection/blood transfusion)...but it sounds like we are all getting through this without that intervention (unless I missed someone?)...we need to stay healthy, eat healthy with the holidays coming ... I hope none of us get this H1N1 flu...are you all getting the flu shot?  I was talking to a nurse that is on chemo and she told me that it is senseless to get it as during chemo, we are unable to produce antibodies, and the chemo pretty much wipes out the inactive anti virus. Others say "yes", get the flu vaccine. Seems there are two schools of thought out there? Regardless, I hope none of us falls ill during this time and come though shiny :)  Are any of you making plans for Halloween? What do you think about that? My friend was suggesting I be a frightening nurse and wear a mask that filters viriuses and wear gloves and actually go to a party.  My next chemo (#4) is in 10/29/09...two days before the party.  Trying to decide if I dare bother. :)  What will you be doing?

I am worried about you and am sad you feel you are to blame because you permitted some weight gain. That's not a lot different than myself blaming taking birth control pills all those years...which is certainly more likely than due to your weight.  My goodness...I hope you will come to realize that you did not bring this on by that...I hope you are feeling better at this time... hugs sweetie.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2010 10:41PM sanaisa wrote: Lisa, I am in the same camp as you...I had the BRCA testing done right after the first surgery with the highly amplified Her2/neu results. The Onc could not understand why I got this as all other factors they consider put me in a very low risk category. I actually think they were hoping the BRCA would help explain it away.  The conclusion in my case is because of all the hormones...whether from the birth control pill or consuption of conventionally raised cattle/poultry (due to additive growth hormones).  They classify the causation as "environmental", meaning something that was introduced to my body that did not naturally occur.  My modus operandi going forward is only to consume animal products (dairy/meats) that are hormone free, of course no hormone replacement, and no more than 2 drinks a week (my Onc told me that a 4-6 ounce glass of wine a night for 6 nights a week is very bad (please know that I did not have a glass of wine every night before!).  I will continue with regular exercise... and of course the remaining 2.5 years of Zometa and 1/2 year of Herceptin.  I am afraid to take Tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor...we'll see after Rads are done in 2.5 weeks! :) love...
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2010 01:35AM sanaisa wrote: Hiya Unklezwifeonty!  I am doing well, thank you hun.  I have my final treatment of Herceptin this week and will hopefully get the darned port removed next week.  Still on the Zometa trial and taking the darned Femara (I hate the Femara SE's...they are real and not imagined).  How are you doing??  My hair is REALLY growing...very exciting to have a full head of hair again :)  I am sure you do, too...  Hugs

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2009 09:49PM sanaisa wrote: Hi Brie and Melinda (thank you for the nice thoughts...and commisserating)...I hate to say it is "reassuring" to hear you are having some similiar sensations, but of course, I sincerely wish none of these SE on any of us.  Oh yes, the darn scalp sensations... I have to admit, I'd trade this heart thing for 10x the scalp thingy...or course, the awful taste part is not much fun.  Is that more unique to the Herceptin, or all we all getting that awfulness?  It almost seems that everything has a similar awful smell, too.  It doesn't smell metallic to me (like some people I hear from)... it's a strage sweetness that just lingers.  Okay...  will stop!  :) Only to know I am not completely insane (maybe just a little!). I always seem to oversee some of the updates (I don't know why?)...can I blame it on the chemo? Just when I think I am current, I realize I am still 4-5 hours behind all of your comments, so I am sorry for not mentioning you in the prior note.  It was not intentional, it's really my ineptness here in this board.  I appreciate all of you...  Welcome Michele...my gosh, you are having weekly treatments x 12? And you have a 12 year old football player!!  I understand what you mean about not wanting to rush through each moment we are given.  When read your words, I realized that this is exactly what I have been doing.  I don't want to complain right now...each moment is precious, and I appreciate it :) Any Ryder, you are simply a rock star...nothing else but that!  What chemo are you on again? Oh! One last question, what does "DH" mean?  Does it mean Dear Husband?  I know it's not "Darned Hangnail!"?  I know I am way off...but I have to know as I see so many of you mention your "DH" (I know I don't have one... Good night ladies...xoxo
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2009 12:55PM sanaisa wrote: Hi revricki...that is amazing...one more thing to learn on the boards!  I had the lowest BP of my life last week of 60/102 ... they did not seem worried about it and I do not know if that is low.  I usually have around 70/110. My pulse has been higher, so maybe you are right.  I have heard that a quickened pulse can be attributable to dehydration.  I think I am rebounding from chemo #2 (after that horrid steriod experience I had) with #3 coming up on October 8th.  I will be 1/2 was finished on Oct 8th!  Three more to go after October 8th...hoping to stay on schedule.  Hopefully now that you have reached day 7, it is downhill for you until the next TC...I hope your next 14 days are better with no more down time.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2009 12:54PM sanaisa wrote: Scoobydoo...so sorry about your ankle pain?  I did not have that with the Neupogen, but I had the horrible hip pains and lower back rib cage pain.  The Claritin is the only thing that worked for me. Melinda ... boy, do I know the Steriod thing!  I don't know if you saw my post about it after my second chemo, but it was REALLY bad.  I have never felt that bad in my life. I had 3x the dosage I should have had, and they didn't titrate (taper) me off the steriods.  I remember it being bad after the first chemo, but nothing like the second.  I hear it has a cumulative effect (all of it).  I thought it was the chemo until the 2nd Onc explained what happens with too much steriod.  Chemo #3 is this Thursday and the steriods will be dramatically reduced.  I have seen first hand a woman go into anaphylactic shock from the Taxotere, and it was FRIGHTENING, so, there is a reason they want to give us these steriods.  Just not too much!! I think the steriod part of the treatment is almost worse than the chemo.  This is why I said that "there is life after steroids".  I call it steroid hell...HORRIBLE. Brie...I understand the depression.  Please tell your Onc about this to make sure it's not from the steriods.  I was embarrassed and almost didn't mention this to my 2nd opinion Onc, but when I explained all my symptoms, he took down a list of all my meds and we found out that I had had way too much steroid medication, thus, the unhappy mental state (I almost called 911 as I have never felt like that in my life...I thought it was the chemo).  I don't want to scare you, but the steriods can have a very strong impact on your mental well-being.  When did you go off the steriods?  They take 7-12 days to work out of your system.   Please hang tough...you will get through this.  I hear the neoadjunt treatment is among the more higher quality forms of treatment, so hang in there. Yes, it is very frustrating to find out some of these things in the boards.  I cannot help but wonder if the Onc/NP doesn't tell us what to expect/what may happen as they are afraid of the placebo effect (which to me is a crock as when things happen, we generally "dismiss" it, or think we are crazy)... chime in when something doesn't seem right.  You are your best advocate (I know you know that, but it bears repeating for me to hear myself...there's no point in suffering or going this alone). Hopbird... oh joy! Don't you just love the hip pain from those WBC booster shots they give us!!?  Ugh!  hugs to you all....

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2009 02:56AM sanaisa wrote: Hi Onty, Anita, MRSb45, Brunettesrule, Lisaa401, Hopbird and Brie (and anyone else that I am sorry to have not named!)...I just wanted to jump in here and say that I hope your Hannukah (if that's what you celebrated) was wonderful and that your Christmas will be beautiful.  I am so excited for the new year.  It sounds like everyone here will be finished with Chemo in December, so it is definitely a reason to celebrate the New Year!  My last chemo made me feel very ill, but oddly, as ill as it made it, I missed one day of work and feel better now than I have felt in a while (probably just the mental aspect of having the first big hurdle behind).  My GI problems have abated and after the first 5 chemos, we finally got the meds (steriods and anti-nausea) right in chemo 6...wow, what a journey that was, huh!!? On to the new rads horizon, continuing Herceptin for a year, trying to get into the SWOG 0307 and Hormone therapy and hopefully HAIR! Gosh...I really miss the hair!  Hugs to you all...  I am moving over to Onty's Rads board now.  Maybe some of you will join us there.  BEST WISHES XOXOXO <3 <3 <3

Posts.Content: May 29, 2010 09:09AM sanaisa wrote: Hi Lisa...popped in to see what's going on in here...been awhile.  So happy to hear of your first trim...yes, it is exciting!  I am getting my third trim tomorrow :)... I have close to 3 inches and it has been so nice to be coverless! I am finally at a stage where the head is no longer recognized as a chemo head.  I remember counting down until June...it's almost here.  Hipe all are doing well.  I really didn't enjoy the first weeks of Femara...but it's getting easier.  Have had 4 of the monthly Zometa's (I am on the bisphophonates trial) and 13 Herceptins left to go.  I can't wait to get the dratted port removed.  Hugs...
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: May 30, 2010 09:38AM sanaisa wrote: Hi Mary...funny you ask that!  I was asking my hairdresser about her thoughts on my hair now, versus prior to chemo.  I asked her to be honest and not worry about my feelings...she told me exactly what I had also thought...that it was surprising, after all that we hear of other people, that my new hair is growing back in just as it was prior to chemo.  It is still the same fine straight light brown texture it was...at first it started very fine, but all of it is growing uniformly.  It is definitely thicker now as we took a photo of it on April 10 (the las time she did my hair) and today.  It is definitely an inch longer, and looks fuller.  Very large difference in less than two months.  We highlighted it today, and I am happy with it :)  So no, no "chemo" hair :)

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2009 09:03PM sanaisa wrote: Hi Ladies...I haven't been contributing as I feel too down to say anything meaningful. :(  I had #4 last Thurs and am counting to day #7 post last treatment. The naseau has been the worst I have had...I had it pretty good with the first three.  I only have two treatments of this TC left (I keep telling myself that).  Like Hopbird, I have Hercepting for a year (18 of those, 1x every three weeks).  I am hoping to make all my counts for treatment #5 on 11/19/09, than hoping/praying to be done with #6 on 12/10/09.  I am so tired, already of being bald and ugly. My ex husband told me the other day that had I not left him two years ago, he would have been with me at my side through this whole thing (gee, that makes me feel good when he wasn't with him for the reason I left him).  It is so lonely doing this with no family or husband to gain support from.  I have a handful of good friends, and my 17 year old daughter is amidst her recent love...it is a lonely place this chemo world.  I just want to get back to normal.  I feel like I have aged 10 years in the past two months.  I am sorry...I am so depressed :(  Just want to be normal again.  Hugs to you all...I hope you all are doing better than me.  ....
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2009 07:58PM sanaisa wrote: Hi Hopbird...my Onc told me "no, no, no" with taking the Ibuprophen (Advil) during my chemo. This makes me sad,as Ibuprophen is my favorite of all pain relievers.  I can't take Ibuprophen because my platelets are not rebounding like they should and Ibuprophen actually works as a blood thinner right now.  I can only take Acetominophen/Tylenol, which, honestly, does not seem to do squat for me, and I am afraid of the damage it can cause to the liver, just as you note! I have enough stuff floating around in my body with this chemo. I am sure my liver is screaming for relief...poor little guy. So, I just do not bother with the pain relievers at this point...the Claritin is the only thing I can take, and I only take it when I think I need it, it seems to really help with the Neupogen shots, which is clearly objective (not in our head that it works). Anita, I am worried about you...you have to use crutches now?  My gosh...that is horrible!?  Please keep us posted, we are checking in on you regularly. Brie, I hope you are doing okay and starting to feel better. We are checking in on you, too!  unlezwife...good to see you are in good spirits and doing well! So many other September chemo starters do not say pop in here, as often.  I hope everyone is doing okay? hugs...

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2010 08:03PM sanaisa wrote: So sorry Onty...hang in there.... xoxo Anita and Mary, you hang in there, too...we are almost done with the major treatment! I remember our first conversations back in August/September.  Look how far we have all come! In many ways, it seemed an eternity, but hopefully in 4-6 months, we can look back and celebrate knocking it through.  Anita, rock that new wig! At least you don't spend 1/2 hour trying to make what stubble you have look socially acceptible ;)  There are moments when I recall that it was easier to don the wig.  Not that I am not thankful and deeply appreciative of having some hair again, but the wig was fast! Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2011 11:14PM sanaisa wrote: Wow, our board is so quiet compared to the Starting Chemo October 2009 board.  Happy New Year to everyone...how are you all doing? Quick update for me:  About 4 weeks ago I had some swelling and strong pain in my breast (the same one where the creeper was) as the pinpoint location where the incision was.  I read in here (in the general articles) that if a pain comes, watch it for two weeks; if it doesn't abate, call your onc.  Well, mine peaked around day 8-10 and I had real pain.  This wasn't the normal breast tenderness you get with menstruation (even though I have not had that in a long ass while, I still recall!).  It bothered me and since I had not seen my onc since I finished Herceptin in August 2010, I made an appt. So...while the pain is gone, he has me down for an ultra sound exam of the breast and a PET scan (never had one of those).  Possibilities are that the pain was attributable to scar tissue, or perhaps some fluid (as I had swelling) built and then subsided.  I won't get these tests for about 2 weeks.  But, am curious, did any of you have something similar to this, after the fact? Happy New Year!!!

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2010 11:50AM sanaisa wrote: Hi Deborah...I was told to wait 6 months PFC for full blown peroxide or bleach coloring.  I had a non peroxide wash put in my hair in March and in April my hairdresser used a cap on me to pull the hairs through (to help so that lightening agents would not touch my scalp.  The result each time was wonderful.  Last Saturday, May 29, I had a full blown weave with peroxide based colors (which was close enough to 6 most PFC for me!). :)   All is good...
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2009 02:01PM sanaisa wrote: Hi Jenm24...if you find out where to donate your hair, please let me know as I would be more than happy to donate my hair to a reputable organzation (not someone trying to make money for personal gain). I am getting my hair lopped tomorrow and will rubber band it in sections as we go for donating. My hair has gotten even longer since my thumbnail pic that was taken last February, so there is a lot to give :). I know that caucasian hair is horribly expensive and in the natural virgin wigs, they charge by the ounce. Very very expensive. Here's a thought: I was told you can use your locks to make extensions...that might be something you can give your Mom as a gift for when her hair starts to regrow!  What a precious daughter you are!!!! hugs...xoxox
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2009 04:21PM sanaisa wrote: I love coming in here to see how you all are doing!  Lena, I can completely relate with your story...my hair is the only accessory to my body that I have ever had that made me feel presentable.  I have lost 90% of my hair and will have my 3rd treatment of 6 this week.  I am "supposed' to be done with the primary 6 treatments in December, and will continue with the Herceptin for 18 treatments (one year).  I have three wigs, one of which was very expensive and is caucasian hair...while the wig with caucasian hair is very nice and realistic, I hate the tape.  My scalp really hurts come 5 PM (I am working full time) and I can barely stand it.  I bought some super soft cashmere beanies last weekend and I love those.  I already hate hats, and I hate wigs more, and I haven't even started.  When did you guys lose your eyelashes?  Was it after your #3 or #4 chemo....or did it happen even later?  My leg hair hasn't needed shaving for a few weeks, same with the underarm.  The nether region is albeit sparse!  To me, the hair loss is the greatest loss.  I was in a meeting today with mostly men and I was actually thinking cranky negative thoughts...looking at them.  Half of them are almost bald, all of them had super short cut hair and I was thinking to myself how they would have frowned upon me had I gone to this meeting bearing my ugly molted bare head.  I can't look at myself in the mirror either...I try not to.  My girlfriend (that is a hairdresser) suggested we give the chemo girl her own name, as when she and I saw her, we didn't recognize her as me.  The hair loss is traumatic...deeply traumatic.  It is going to be a VERY long year coming.  But, I come back here and pray, scratch, claw, for hope that come 9 weeks, I will see sproutings of my old self resurface.  I miss the girl I was...I hope she comes back. You guys keep me positive... xoxoxo
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2009 06:12PM sanaisa wrote: Aw... hrf...I have been catching up in here and I wish I could suggest anything.  I have only finished chemo #3, and will have #4 on 10/29...#5 will be in November and #6 will be in early December.  I am counting to April 29, 2010 with hopes that I will have sprouts by week 20 (that will be the 20th week post final TC).  I will be on Herceptin IV's every 3 weeks for a year, so we will see if that slows me down.  I am thinking of getting the Nioxin #2 Cleansing Shampoo, Scalp Conditioner and Scalp Treatment, or the Sally's Beauty alternative...to get it ready to start three weeks after I finish the final #6.  In reading your posts though, it sounds like SOMETHING is happening?  Everytime you write, I see you are sad as it is not growing, but it seems with every posting, you have a little more.  You are saying now that it's dark with a sprinkling of gray :)  That's a lot more than you were saying a month ago!  I am going to stock up on the Biotin that lisalisa recommends. I am a little over a year behind you (I think) :)  I will be checking in here for the next year to see how long your hair will be to give me hope.  hugs... P.S. Thanks Chelev for the wonderful brow info!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2009 06:14PM sanaisa wrote: purpleme....your eyebrows are absent 10 months PFC?  My gosh... This whole hair loss deal is really so awful.  So strange, this morning when I woke up, my eyebrows (what's left of 'em!) were "aching" a little...felt a little like they were standing up on edge (reminded me of how my scalp felt before my hair actually fell out).  I am 3 weeks PFC and I am guessing that the remainder of my brows will be leaving very soon...I have about 30% of my eyelashes...babying those guys! Yes, I have lots of white hairs scattered throughout the top (that's the only place there are white hairs?)...lots of fine baby hairs mixed in, too.  The hair on my head is definitely sprouting...just looks so fine and delicate.  Can still see some of my scalp near the temples and back side...maybe in a month or so...
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2010 05:32PM sanaisa wrote: Bold, would love the see the extensions, too! That's awesome! How many inches of growth did you have before you put them in? Would love the name of the person that did your extensions (I am in Woodland Hills)...I know I am at least 5-8 months from that, but it is something to look forward to!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2010 07:43PM sanaisa wrote: Just a quick update...9 weeks PFC and my head is covered with very dense hair.  The scalp is no longer visible at all...even if I try to find it. Been using the Nioxin scalp treatment and taking Prenatal vitamins since finishing chemo (my Onc told me that if anything will help the hair grow fuller and faster, it will be the Prenatal vitamins...so, taking those!)  I thought it would never happen!  I went and had the tiniest trim last weekend (to get rid of the chemo whispies) and I am hoping that in one more month, I will have enough to dye the tips a nice blonde and go coverless. For now, I still don the cover, as my ears have no covering yet! I am going to try for the short style that Ellen Degeneres was sporting on Idol this week :)  I thought it was pretty cute: http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2010/02/10/article-1249901-0838DFD9000005DC-893_468x457.jpg
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2009 11:03PM sanaisa wrote: Hi Journey-Girl...I wondered about that...I have needed to shave three times (legs and underarms) since starting chemo (going for number four, Taxotere/Carboplatin/Herceptin on 10/29).  I lost a lot of hair, but actually regret cutting it down to 1/4 inch. It was falling out in clumps and I was convinced it would all be gone, so, we shaved it off with a guard. Since cutting it off (also a most horrible day for me), the hairs that remained (about 30%) have continued to grow.  I don't understand it? I have not heard from anyone that they lost all their hair...I always had a lot of hair, but it is fine. It seems the finest hairs have remained...I have not lost any hair on my arms (which are also fine and blonde).  It seems the fine, lighter hairs have hung around. My hair is definitely more dense on top, too...it's the sides that are sparse and you can see my scalp when looking.  But, I don't have enough to go without a headcover.  But, this is NOTHING like the full head of hair I used to have.  Most definitely.  I cannot wait to be done with chemo and already have week 20 from PFC marked on my calendar as my "hopeful" time to have something normal sprouting on my head. Like you, I practically pee myself thinking that I am 1/2 way done (three to go...next one on 10/29, then 11/17 and finally 12/10...ceteris paribus!!). I am prepared to lose my eyebrows and eyelashes sometime in December, as it seems everyone loses theirs a couple/three weeks post the final chemo? I am sure all of you had some hair on your head through chemo, right? Did you all get slow growth on your legs and underarms?  I won't get into the sparse private region!!! LOL
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2010 06:57PM sanaisa wrote: Hi Juannelle...I should have mentioned that my Onc told me that one of the bonuses to the Prenatal vitamins is the Zinc.  He said that this is clinically found to be beneficial.  I asked about the Biotin...he said I could take it, but didn't believe it was helpful.  Who knows.  I have the Biotin (5000K dosage) too...but for now, am only taking the Prenatals as I am undergoing Rads.  The Nioxin is a little stinky, and I don't know if it actually helps the hair follicles, but it certainly makes the hair have a thicker texture (until you wash it out!).  LOL I should clarify, my hair is only about 1/2 long...not that long.  I am just happy that it is dense and my scalp is finally filled in with hair.  It's gonna be a slow go...but, at least its going!!! ;) So fun to put shampoo in it and actually have it foam up again...forgot what that was like.  Someday, I hope to feel the little guys move with the wind...then it will be reality! Have a great weekend...hugs
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2010 11:07PM sanaisa wrote: Janny...we are there with you.  I know...I was so upset about the hair loss.  I don't understand why they cannot find a way to infuse chemo and save the hair.  I would shower every day and wash my hair as gently as possible...counting down to 17 days after my first chemo, and hoping, begging, praying I would not lose my hair.  I lost at least 80% of it, if not more.  I was never shiny bald, but I was bald in all "reasonable" measures.  I had my first chemo on 8/27/09 and by 9/17/09, my hair was pretty much gone. It starts gradually, and then clumps over 2-5 days :(  I remember sobbing in the shower...  my hair is the one thing I had as a woman that made me feel feminine.  I was able go coverless for the first time in mid March 2010 (really) with about 3/4 inch of hair (but my scalp was covered, dark...no empty skin spots).  I had my first hair coloring on 4/10/10, along with a trim and ended up at close to 2 inches...I went to Coachella to party it up with my friends...  I had my hair touched up again last weekend as I have had so much growth...close to 3 inches now.  I hear that once we stop the Herceptin, it grows REALLY fast (I am telling you this as you are on the same treatment as me).  I wish I knew how to post a photo so you could see... :)  Just remember it grows back...  I'll admit, I went to a party last Saturday and out of about 40 girls, I was the ONLY one with short hair. I felt like I stood out like a sore thumb, but no-one seemed to notice or care.  I wasn't treated any differently. I may not "feel" as pretty with shorter hair, but it seems no-one really cares :)  It is difficult going out there at first...you definitely have to work more on the facial make-up... but it is doable, and gets better every week. And I would swear my eye-lashes are fuller and longer than they ever have been.  I keep waiting for them to fall out again...I hope they don't, and sofar, they haven't. Regarding new hair growth... I remember picking my "date" that I fully expected to have enough hair to go topless (I picked early April...5 months PFC...which I thought/hoped would be realistic based upon all the other posters in this forum). I ended up being able to start going coverless a month sooner, in mid March :)  Which really surprised me. I don't know if using the Nioxin helped (used the scalp treatment, shampoo and conditioner), or the vitamins I started taking three weeks after chemo...I tend to be a cynic, but I figured it couldn't hurt and my Onc didn't have any concerns with them (I showed him the bottles).  Looking forward really helps, picking a date and planning something special for yourself at about 5 months PFC is a super nice carrot.  I don't know...it really helped me...  now I am counting down the weekly H's!  I cannot wait to get the port removed come September...that's my next countdown :)  What's your countdown to 5 months PFC? :)
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2009 02:41PM sanaisa wrote: You guys are GREAT! Making me laugh!  Chelev, you and your "don't run too fast"...so that whatever remains "hanging on" does not fall out!  LOL!   chrisct: I used to do that, too!  Hang the cardigan off my head to pretend I have long hair.  When I was 5 years old, I had long hair and my dear grandma was my caretaker at the time.  One morning she could not comb through my long locks and cut them off into the craziest pixie...I remember being horrified and going to school that day with a chopped mess.  I remember putting my cardigan on my head and running around in the play-yard, pretending to have my long hair back.  I forgot about that memory.  So sad that now, I have even less hair than at that time! Thank you littlered and ChrisC433...your positive affirmations are the perk I needed today.  I went to work with a nicer scarf today and no-one stared or made me feel weird.  Very supportive.  People are telling me I look nice (I think they are being kind, but it does not matter, at least they are kind, and this is what truly matters). Rachel, you are too funny with the Uncle Chester and Guinan reference.  You got me thinking "Ch-Ch-Ch-Chia!"... maybe I can put some sprouts on my head and grow 'em...the newest rage in Chia Pets. Thank you jancie, hrf and stef58 for your thoughts, too... Laughing a LOT today... a day before chemo #3 Thanks guys!!! xoxoxo  Just what I needed today, really. <3
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2009 01:53PM sanaisa wrote: Hi Cabmom...I am in the process of renting the Cold Caps...the cost about $30 per cap to rent, and I need 14 of them ($420 a month). I was hoping to get by with 8 of them, as it takes 2 hours refreeze them after use.  I figure in changing them every 1/2 hour, over a period of 6 hours, as long as I have two in the freezer straight from adding the new set, I should be okay?  That would save me $180 and reduce the total monthly cost down to $240). Unfortunately, I found about them too late and already missed out on my first chance to use them (had my first Taxotere/Carboplatin/Herceptin) treatment on 8/27/09 and my hair started to sparse two days ago...I am getting my hair cut very short tomorrow.  I am going to venture into using the Cold Caps with next week's treatment on 9/17/09 in hopes of minimizing any further damage to the hair follicles, and, based on what the represenative from Cold Caps told me, I should expect to see the regrowth of my lost hair start to come back in a couple of months.  The US number for Penguin Cold Caps is 714-982-8846.  Regarding availability, I am not sure. My set is available to me locally as I am taking them over from a woman that is finishing up with her rental (lucky soul!); the Cold Caps baton is being passed to me.  These Neupogen shots are nocking me off my socks...anyone else have SE with these shots? I feel like I have a bad flu, but fortunately no fever! :)
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2009 04:31PM sanaisa wrote: Rachel_BC...thanks for the funny, great pics! LOL!  You are wonderful! chelev...is this the product by Benefit? http://www.sephora.com/browse/product.jhtml?id=P1274 ... Anastasia has so many brow products, I could not figure out which one is the one you are recommending.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2009 08:15PM sanaisa wrote: Ladies, what can we do about the viable option of word getting out to future chemo patients that Penguins Cold Caps may help save the majority of one's hair?  I found out from the Septemer 2009 treatment group that a couple of ladies are wearing them are having success.  One lady, Newportlori , visited us to tell us that she has had three TCH treatments and has only lost a very small amount of hair (around her ears and nape of neck) as the Cold Cap didn't sufficiently chill that section of her head.  She is having wonderful success. I am so happy for her! I just received a call from Penguins Cold Caps and they said that sadly, as I already had my first treatment with unprotected hair follicles (sounds like I had unprotected sex and now am getting an STD!), my hair cannot be saved.  This is very sad...so many people do not need to lose their hair. I wish you all the best with your regrowth...actually I am right behind you..."way" behind you hugs...
